aboutSection.firstText: ResiliencyGardens.org is a charitable organization dedicated to educating future generations by investing in school and community gardens that showcase sustainable agricultural practices, promote healthy living, and foster environmental stewardship.
aboutSection.secondText: To create dynamic, hands-on learning environments that deepen our understanding of ecological processes, while inspiring people of all ages to experience the joy of growing and eating their own food.
aboutSection.thirdText: A world where communities are resilient, self-sufficient, and actively engaged in sustainable food systems that foster personal well-being and contribute to the health of our planet.

mattersSection.title: Why it matters
mattersSection.firstText: The deterioration of our natural environment endangers our well-being and future of today’s youth.
mattersSection.secondText: By equipping youth with critical thinking, problem-solving skills, and resilience, we prepare them to tackle global challenges and become responsible citizens committed to a sustainable future.

first.title: 1. Start a school or community garden
first.text: Starting a school or community garden is a powerful way to bring people together, foster hands-on learning, and promote healthy living. These gardens serve as living classrooms that teach sustainable practices, connect individuals with nature, and inspire a sense of pride in growing and sharing fresh, nutritious food.

firstItem.title: Grant Opportunities
firstItem.text: As funds become available, ResiliencyGardens.org provides support for school and community garden infrastructure, covering expenses for construction materials, soil, seeds, and tools, as well as educational resources, including instructors and workshops. We invite you to explore our grant programs below to find the one that best suits your needs.

second.title: 2. Start your own garden
second.subtext: Anyone can grow vegetables and everyone enjoys watching a seed they planted sprout and grow. Whether on a windowsill, a balcony or in a garden bed, we can all make a difference.
second.firstText: People who have access to their own vegetable garden consume 40% more fresh vegetables and herbs and, consequently, eat less junk food.
second.secondText: Vegetables and herbs lose 30-50% of their useful properties within 5-10 days. Local vegetable gardens allow you to eat vegetables and herbs immediately after harvesting.
second.thirdText: Working in a garden has a positive effect on personal well-being and gardening with others enhances social connections.

startSection.title: Where to start?
startSection.firstText: If you’ve no land, it doesn’t mean you can’t garden.
startSection.secondText: A garden has four basic needs:

pointsSection.title: Soil.
pointsSection.text: Great soil is essential to growing vegetables, fruits, and other plant life.

pointsSection.title: Sun.
pointsSection.text: Most vegetables need at least 6 hours of unobstructed sun or artificial light per day, although some crops, such as broccoli, lettuce, spinach, and other greens, can tolerate less.

pointsSection.title: Water.
pointsSection.text: Plants need water for essential biological processes that enable them to grow, thrive and reproduce.

pointsSection.title: Seeds.
pointsSection.text: Source and buy quality seeds locally that are suitable for your climate and your type of garden.

sliderSection.title: What you need
sliderSection.text: There are many ways to garden: in-ground garden beds, raised rows, raised garden beds, straw bales, and container gardens

cards.title: Sensory development
cards.text: A garden is a place of wonder for a child. Children are absorbed by the textures, shapes, colors and scents of living plants and thrilled when they can enjoy their taste.  Gardening helps kids develop hand-eye coordination and build physical strength and important motor skills, such as cutting, planting, and writing.

cards.title: Intellectual skills
cards.text: Gardening involves planning, a skill that everyone needs. Kids should be included in this process. Support them in learning how to prepare the soil, plant, water, and weed.  They can report on what they have done already and what they think they should do next. In time, they will be able to identify the differences and characteristics of roots, stems, flowers, leaves, seeds and fruits. Gardening is a fun way to help kids learn something useful!

cards.title: Social skills
cards.text: Kids learn to cooperate by working together to nurture and care for their plants. They can paint flowerpots together and share their knowledge of different plants. Through planting trees or plants at school, they can meet new friends, gain status and expand their knowledge.

cards.text: Trips Beyond the Classroom offers Innovative Education that creates lifetime and generational impact by inspiring future leaders. A special Beyond the Garden program supported five educational institutions in creating young environmental stewards through gardening.

Seed Programs International provides good quality seed, expertise, and training materials to humanitarian organizations working around the world to alleviate hunger and poverty. SPI’s in-kind grants have helped 27 schools in Poland to establish Resiliency Gardens for learning and sharing.

KidsGardening.org creates opportunities for kids to play, learn, and grow through gardening. KG’s in-kind donation of Learning Tools for educators, parents and child caregivers are now available in Polish and Ukrainian.

Rybnik, in southern Poland, leads in sustainable food practices. Through the StratKIT+ project, Rybnik has matched 10% of Resiliency Gardens grants, improving school garden infrastructure. Since 2024, 4,562 students from eleven schools are participating in gardening, enhancing community engagement and integrating sustainable food systems into education.
